The fasting blood levels of glucose for a group of diabetics is found to be normally distributed with a mean of 105 mg per 100 ml of blood and a standard deviation of 10 mg per 100 ml of blood . From this data is can be inferredthat approximately 95% of diabetic will have inferred that approximately 95% of diabetic will have their fasting blood level within the limit of :
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Given:
  • • Mean (μ) = 105 mg/dL Standard deviation (σ) = 10 mg/dL 95% of values lie within ±2 standard deviations of the mean
  • • Lower limit=μ−2σ=105−(2×10)=85 mg/dL
  • • Upper limit=μ+2σ=105+(2×10)=125 mg/dL
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • (A) 75 and 135 mg/dL: This range corresponds to ±3σ, which includes approximately 99.7% of the data, not 95%.
  • • (C) 95 and 115 mg/dL: This range represents ±1σ, covering 68% of the data rather than 95%, making it incorrect.
  • • (D) 65 and 145 mg/dL: This range is ±4σ, which includes almost 100% of the data, much broader than the 95% confidence interval.

questions.text: A Population study showed a mean glucose of 86 mg/ dL. In a sample of 100 showing normalcurve distribution . What percentage of peoplehave glucose above 86mg/dL:
Pearson’s skewness coefficient is given by :
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Pearson's skewness coefficient is a measure of the asymmetry of a distribution. The formula compares the mean and mode to indicate the direction and degree of skewness:
  • • If Skewness > 0 (Positive Skew): Mean > Mode > Right-skewed (tail on the right) If Skewness < 0 (Negative Skew): Mean < Mode > Left-skewed (tail on the left) If Skewness = 0: The distribution is approximately symmetric
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • (B) Mode - Mean / SD: The formula is incorrect because the standard formula is Mean - Mode, not the other way around.
  • • (C) SD / (Mean - Median): This is incorrect because the numerator should be (Mean - Mode), not SD. Pearson’s second coefficient of skewness (another version) is actually: 3(Mean - Median)/Standard Deviation But this is different from the first coefficient.
  • • (D) SD / (Median - Mean): Incorrect because standard deviation is not used in the numerator. Also, the difference should be Mean - Mode or Mean - Median, not the reverse.

questions.text: Q-test is used for detecting :
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Interquartile Range (IQR): • The IQR is used to measure data spread and identify outliers, but it is not part of the Q-test. • The IQR method typically identifies outliers as data points below Q1 - 1.5×IQR or above Q3 + 1.5×IQR.
  • • (C) Difference of Mean: • The Q-test does not compare means between groups; instead, tests like the t-test or ANOVA are used for mean differences.
  • • (D) Difference of Proportions: • The Q-test is not used to compare proportions; statistical tests like the Z-test for proportions or Chi-square test are used instead.

questions.text: Mean hemoglobin of a group of pregnant females is found to be 10.6 gm/ dL with Standard deviation of 2 gm/dL. 5% pregnant females in this group will have their hemoglobin level below :
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) 8.6 gm/dL: This corresponds to a Z-score closer to -1.0, which would include more than 5% of the population in the lower tail.
  • • (C) 6.6 gm/dL: This is too extreme; it would correspond to a Z-score lower than -1.645, meaning fewer than 5% of the population would be below this value.
  • • (D) 5.0 gm/dL: This is an even more extreme value and would correspond to a much lower percentile (far below 5%), making it incorrect.

questions.text: In a standard normal curve the area between one standard deviation on either side will be :
About standard normal curve all is true except :
Normal distribution curve is determined by :
For calculating of sample size for a prevalence study all of the following are necessary except :
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • For a prevalence study, the sample size is determined using the formula:
  • • n= Z 2 P(1-P)/d 2
  • • • P = Prevalence of disease in the population (from prior studies or estimates)
  • • • Z = Z-score corresponding to the chosen significance level (α) (usually 1.96 for 95% confidence)
  • • • d = Absolute precision (or margin of error)
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • (A) Prevalence of disease in the population (Necessary)
  • • • The sample size calculation depends directly on the estimated prevalence (P) of the disease. If P is unknown, an assumption or pilot study is required.
  • • (C) Significance level (Necessary)
  • • • The significance level (α) determines the confidence level (e.g., 95% confidence corresponds to α = 0.05). This affects the Z-value used in the formula.
  • • (D) Absolute precision (Necessary)
  • • • Precision (d) represents the margin of error in prevalence estimation. A smaller d requires a larger sample size for better accuracy.

questions.text: In a particular trial the association of lung cancer with smoking is found to be 40% in one sample and 60% in another . What is the best test to compare the result:
Height of group of 20 boysaged 10 years was 140 + 13 cm & 20 girl of same age was135 cm + 7 cm to test the statisticalsignificance of difference in height test applicable is:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Chi-square (χ 2 ) Test The chi-square test is used for categorical data (e.g., gender, presence/absence of a disease). Since we are comparing numerical (continuous) data (height in cm), chi-square is not appropriate.
  • • (B) Z-test A Z-test is used when the sample size is large (n > 30) and the population standard deviation is known. Since n = 20 in both groups and we are not given the population standard deviation, the t-test is preferred.
  • • (D) F-test An F-test is used to compare variances of two or more groups, not their means. Since the question asks for a test to compare the mean heights, the t-test is more appropriate

questions.text: The mean B.P of a group personwas determine and after an interventionaltrial the mean BP was estimated again . The best to be applied to determine the significance of intervention is :
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Chi-square (χ 2 ) Test Chi-square is used for categorical data (e.g., presence/absence of hypertension). Since BP is continuous numerical data, chi-square is not appropriate.
  • • (C) Correlation Coefficient Correlation measures the strength and direction of a relationship between two variables (e.g., BP vs. age). It does not test whether there is a significant difference before and after an intervention.
  • • (D) Independent t-test An independent t-test compares two separate groups (e.g., Group A vs. Group B). Here, we are comparing BP in the same individuals before and after an intervention, so the paired t-test is more appropriate.

questions.correct_answer: A. As the sample size increases , standard error will also increase

questions.text: P- value is defined as :

options.label: A
options.text: Probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present

options.label: B
options.text: Probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is present

options.label: C
options.text: Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present

options.label: D
options.text: Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is present

questions.correct_answer: A. Probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is present: - Incorrect. This describes a correct rejection of a false null hypothesis, which is not what the p-value represents. The p-value does not measure the probability that a real difference exists; it only tells us how likely our results are under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true.
  • • (C) Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present: - Incorrect. This describes the correct acceptance of a true null hypothesis, which is unrelated to the p-value.
  • • (D) Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is present: - Incorrect. This describes a Type II error (false negative, β error)—failing to reject a false null hypothesis. The p-value does not measure Type II errors; instead, it is linked to Type I errors.

questions.text: A 95% confidence interval for prevalence of cancer in smokers aged > 65 year is 56% to 76%, the chance that the prevalence could be less than 56% is :
When we say that “the difference is significant” it mean that :

options.label: A
options.text: It is likely by chance and when P > 0.0.5

options.label: B
options.text: It is unlikely by chance and when p> 0.05

options.label: C
options.text: It is unlikely by chance and when < 0.05

options.label: D
options.text: It is likely by chance and when P < 0.05

questions.correct_answer: C. It is unlikely by chance and when < 0.05

questions.text: What will be the 95 % CI for an estimated prevalence of 10% and a sample size of 100

options.label: A
options.text: Given data inadequate for calculation of class intervals

questions.text: In a test of significance , P value is 0.023 the observed difference in study can be considered as :

options.label: B
options.text: Null hypothesis rejected and the study is accepted

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: B. Null hypothesis rejected and the study is accepted

questions.text: If confidence is increased there:
questions.correct_answer: B. Previously significant data becomes insignificant
